quiz.title: Unit 2: Production Possibilities Frontier (Quiz 7)
quiz.subtitle: 2.7 Comparative Advantage: Opportunity Cost in Trade Decisions (20 Questions)
quiz.subject: Economics
quiz.topic: Comparative Advantage, Opportunity Cost Calculations, Trade Specialization

questions.question: A country has a comparative advantage in producing a good when it:
options: Can produce more of the good than other countries
Has the lowest opportunity cost of producing that good
Uses the most advanced technology for that good
Has the largest domestic market for that good
questions.explanation: Comparative advantage is determined solely by opportunity cost - the country that gives up the least of other goods to produce a particular good has the comparative advantage in that good.

questions.question: The fundamental basis for mutually beneficial trade is:
questions.explanation: Differences in comparative advantage (opportunity costs) create the potential for gains from trade. Even if one country has absolute advantage in everything, both can benefit when they specialize according to comparative advantage.

questions.question: Country A: 1 unit of cloth = 2 units of wine. Country B: 1 unit of cloth = 3 units of wine. Which country has comparative advantage in cloth?
questions.explanation: Country A gives up only 2 wine to produce 1 cloth, while Country B gives up 3 wine. Since Country A has lower opportunity cost for cloth, it has comparative advantage in cloth.

questions.question: David Ricardo's theory of comparative advantage demonstrates that:
options: Only countries with absolute advantage should trade
Trade can benefit all countries regardless of absolute productivity
Trade always benefits rich countries at the expense of poor ones
Countries should be self-sufficient in essential goods
questions.explanation: Ricardo showed that differences in comparative advantage allow all countries to benefit from trade, even if one country is more productive in all goods.

questions.question: If Country X's opportunity cost for cars is 2 trucks, and Country Y's is 4 trucks, which country should specialize in car production?
questions.explanation: Country X has lower opportunity cost for cars (2 trucks vs 4 trucks), so Country X has comparative advantage in cars and should specialize in car production.

questions.question: The 'law of comparative advantage' states that:
options: Countries should export goods they produce most efficiently
Total output is maximized when countries specialize according to opportunity costs
Trade benefits only the more productive country
Opportunity costs are irrelevant in modern trade
questions.explanation: The law of comparative advantage states that world output is maximized when each country specializes in producing goods where it has the lowest opportunity cost.

questions.question: A country can have comparative advantage in a good even if it:
options: Has absolute disadvantage in that good
Has identical productivity to other countries
Does not currently produce that good
questions.explanation: Comparative advantage depends on opportunity costs, not absolute productivity. A country can be less productive in all goods but still have comparative advantage in some goods where its productivity disadvantage is smallest.

questions.question: To determine comparative advantage, you need to compare:
questions.explanation: Comparative advantage is determined by comparing the opportunity cost of producing one good in terms of another good across different countries.

questions.question: If two countries have identical opportunity cost ratios:
options: No basis for mutually beneficial trade exists
Both countries have comparative advantage in all goods
Only one country can benefit from trade
questions.explanation: When opportunity costs are identical, no comparative advantage differences exist, so no mutually beneficial trade based on specialization is possible.

questions.question: The classic Ricardo example of England and Portugal trading cloth and wine demonstrates that:
options: Portugal should not trade since it's more productive in both
Both countries benefit by specializing according to comparative advantage
Absolute advantage determines all trade patterns
Trade benefits only the less productive country
questions.explanation: Ricardo showed that even though Portugal had absolute advantage in both goods, both countries benefited when Portugal specialized in wine (its greater comparative advantage) and England specialized in cloth (its smaller comparative disadvantage).

questions.question: When countries specialize according to comparative advantage, world production:
options: Increases due to more efficient resource allocation
questions.explanation: Specialization according to comparative advantage allows global resources to be allocated to their most productive uses across countries, increasing total world output.

questions.question: A doctor who is better at both medicine and typing than her secretary should:
options: Specialize in medicine and hire the secretary for typing
Split time equally between both tasks
Fire the secretary and type herself
questions.explanation: Even with absolute advantage in both, the doctor has greater comparative advantage in medicine (higher opportunity cost for typing), so she should specialize in medicine and trade for typing services.

questions.question: Comparative advantage explains why:
options: High-wage countries can compete with low-wage countries
All trade benefits flow to developed countries
Countries should produce everything they consume
questions.explanation: Comparative advantage explains how high-wage countries can successfully export goods to low-wage countries by specializing in goods where they have the greatest productivity advantage (lowest opportunity cost).

questions.question: If Country A: 1 computer = 5 phones, and Country B: 1 computer = 3 phones, which country has comparative advantage in phones?
questions.explanation: For phones: Country A's opportunity cost is 1/5 computer per phone, Country B's is 1/3 computer per phone. Country A has lower opportunity cost for phones (0.2 computers vs 0.33 computers), so Country A actually has comparative advantage in phones. Let me recalculate: Country A gives up 5 phones for 1 computer, so 1 phone = 0.2 computers. Country B gives up 3 phones for 1 computer, so 1 phone = 0.33 computers. Country A has lower opportunity cost for phones. The correct answer should be A.

questions.question: The gains from comparative advantage come from:
questions.explanation: The gains from trade based on comparative advantage come from allocating the world's resources to their most productive uses across countries, increasing total global output.

questions.question: A country should import goods in which it has:
questions.explanation: Countries maximize benefits by exporting goods where they have comparative advantage and importing goods where they have comparative disadvantage (higher opportunity cost).

questions.question: Comparative advantage can change over time due to:
options: Changes in technology and resource availability
questions.explanation: Comparative advantage is dynamic - it can shift as countries develop new technologies, discover resources, improve education, or as global demand patterns change.

questions.question: The main assumption of the simple comparative advantage model is:
questions.explanation: The basic Ricardian model assumes constant opportunity costs (linear PPFs), though more advanced models incorporate increasing opportunity costs (bowed-out PPFs).

questions.question: If the opportunity cost of producing wheat is lower in Canada than in Japan, then:
options: Canada should export wheat to Japan
Japan should export wheat to Canada
Both countries should be self-sufficient in wheat
No trade in wheat will occur
questions.explanation: Since Canada has lower opportunity cost for wheat (comparative advantage), it should specialize in wheat production and export wheat to Japan, while Japan specializes in other goods.

questions.question: Comparative advantage is considered one of the most important concepts in economics because it:
options: Explains why free trade can benefit all nations
Guarantees equal benefits for all trading partners
Eliminates the need for economic development
questions.explanation: Comparative advantage provides the fundamental theoretical justification for free trade by demonstrating how all nations can benefit from specialization and exchange, regardless of their absolute productivity levels.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You have mastered the crucial concept of comparative advantage and understand how opportunity costs drive trade patterns.
scoreMessages.70: Good work! You understand comparative advantage but review how to calculate opportunity costs and determine which country has comparative advantage in which good.
scoreMessages.50: A fair start. Focus on: Comparative advantage = lower opportunity cost; calculate what is given up; countries should specialize in what they sacrifice least to produce.
scoreMessages.0: Keep practicing! Remember: Comparative advantage is about opportunity cost, not absolute productivity. The country with lower opportunity cost for a good should specialize in that good.
